Medley against Medley. Wednesday, October 9th, 1811. See Thrusiout on the demise of Turner v. Grey, Stra. 1056; Kinney v. Beverley, 1 H and M. 531; and Moxberry v. Marye, 2 Munf. 453. FROM the declaration in ejectment in this case, it appeared that Elizabeth Medley, the appellee, who was thc lessor of the plaintiff, claimed as tenant f-r life. While the appeal was pending: in this Court she died j and Batts, for the appellant, contended that, a» her title to the land expired at her death; the appeal ought to abate.

An appeal from the a judgments in ejectment does not abate by the death of the leasor of the plaintiffs; notwithstanding such lessor claimed the land for life only.

The Court, after taking time to consider the point, decidéd that the appeal had not abated, and that the cause might be called for trial5 saving to the appellant the liberty to move far security for costs; as to the propriety of which, no opinion was then given.*
